Problem:
Consider a system dynamics where the position \\( x(t) \\) of a particle in a one-dimensional space is governed by the differential equation \\( \\dot{x}(t) = -kx(t) + F(t) \\), with \\( k \\) a positive constant representing damping and \\( F(t) \\) an external force function. The study involves the introduction of a sudden force impulse \\( F(t) = I \\delta(t - t_0) \\), where \\( I \\) is the impulse magnitude and \\( \\delta \\) is the Dirac delta function.

Does the introduction of the impulse at \\( t_0 \\) fundamentally alter the system's state at any time \\( t > t_0 \\) compared to if no impulse were applied?
Explanation: The impulse introduces an instantaneous change in the velocity of the particle, effectively changing its trajectory from that point onward. The evolution of the state \\( x(t) \\) for \\( t > t_0 \\) will reflect this instantaneous shift, diverging from the trajectory had the impulse not been applied.
